panels.description:
This shows the role of the selected instance. Normally this should be one of ``PRIMARY``, ``SECONDARY`` and ``ARBITER``, but if the system is newly added it could show ``STARTUP2`` during its initial sync.

Read more about [Replica Set Member States](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/replica-states/).
panels.title: ReplSet State

panels.description: This shows how many members are configured in the replica set.
panels.title: ReplSet Members

panels.description: This shows the time since the last election.
panels.title: ReplSet Last Election

panels.description: This panel shows how far behind in replication this member is if it is a secondary. This number may be high it the instance is running as a delayed secondary member.
panels.title: ReplSet Lag

panels.description: This shows which storage engine the instance is configured with.
panels.title: Storage Engine

panels.description:
This shows the number of replicated commands that have been sent from the primary to this instance. This will always be empty on a primary instance.

*NOTE*: A single command (such as a call to `.updateMany()`) on the primary can generate multiple replicated commands on a secondary.
panels.title: Replication Operations

panels.description:
This shows how much time the oplog covers. The oplog is a capped (fixed size) collection and the amount of time can grow or shrink as workloads decrease or increase. You want to make sure the oplog is sized big enough to handle the time it takes for maintenance or to sync a secondary member.

Learn more about the [Oplog](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/core/replica-set-oplog/).
panels.title: Oplog Recovery Window

panels.description:
This shows the amount of time that a secondary is behind the primary. A high value could be due the secondary being delayed. If this instance is a normal secondary you will want to check the instance to determine why it is behind and resolve the issue.

Learn more about [Replication Lag](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/troubleshoot-replica-sets/#replica-set-replication-lag).
panels.title: Replication Lag

panels.description:
This shows when elections occur in the replica set. An election happens whenever the primary instance is not accessible to the rest of the members. Looking at this graph over long periods of time can help you to correlate elections to other system events.

Learn more about [Replica set Elections](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/core/replica-set-elections/).
panels.title: Elections

panels.description: This graph shows all replica set members and the amount of time that each member was in a given state.
panels.title: Member State Uptime

panels.description: This chart shows the heartbeat time between this instance and all other instances in the replica set. If there is no heartbeat returned after 10 seconds the node in considered to be unreachable and would require intervention to determine the cause.
panels.title: Max Heartbeat Time

panels.description: This shows the number of milliseconds that a round-trip packet required when communication with other members of the replica set. High values could indicate an issue such as network lag and should be looked into.
panels.title: Max Member Ping Time

panels.description: This is the number of milliseconds that the secondary member spends in getting receiving data from the instance it's replicating from.
panels.title: Oplog Getmore Time

panels.description: This shows the number of operations per second that the secondary member is receiving from its source.
panels.title: Oplog Operations

panels.description: This shows the amount of time it takes a secondary instance to apply data from the oplog.
panels.title: Oplog Processing Time

panels.description: This shows the number of operations that are in the oplog buffer waiting to be applied on the secondary member.
panels.title: Oplog Buffered Operations

panels.description: This shows the maximum size of the oplog buffer and the current amount of data being stored in the buffer. The maximum size is not configurable currently and is set by the `mongod` process.
panels.title: Oplog Buffer Capacity

panels.description:
This shows the number of active connections on the server. Keep in mind the hard limit on the maximum number of connections set by your distribution.

You can read more about the [connection numbers](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/administration/analyzing-mongodb-performance/#number-of-connections).
panels.title: Connections

panels.description: This shows the number of open cursors for each shard in the cluster. A cursor in MongoDB is a pointer to the result of a given query that can be iterated over. By default a cursor times out after 10 minutes.
panels.title: Cursors

panels.description:
Percent of Memory Available
Note: on Modern Linux Kernels amount of Memory Available for application is not the same as Free+Cached+Buffers
panels.title: Memory Available

panels.description: RAM + SWAP
panels.title: Virtual Memory

panels.description: Sum of disk space on all partitions. Note  it can be significantly over-reported in some installations
panels.title: Disk Space

panels.description: Lowest percent of the disk space available
panels.title: Min Space Available

targets.expr: clamp_max(((avg by (mode) ( (clamp_max(rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{node_name=~"$host",mode!="idle"}[$interval]),1)) or (clamp_max(irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{node_name=~"$host",mode!="idle"}[5m]),1)) ))*100 or (avg_over_time(node_cpu_average{node_name=~"$host", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_cpu_average{node_name=~"$host", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[5m]))),100)

panels.title: CPU Saturation and Max Core Usage
